Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ATOL: A Phylogenetic and Genomic Investigation of the Algal Heterokont Tree
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to Robert A. Andersen (Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences, West Boothbay Harbor, Maine), Rose Ann Cattolico and Gabrielle Rocap (University of Washington, Seattle, Washington), Robert Jansen, Elizabeth Ruck and Edward Theriot (University of Texas, Austin Texas), Matt Julius (St. Cloud State University, St. Cloud, Minnesota), Stefano Draisma (National Herbarium and Leiden University, Leiden, The Netherlands) and Hiroshi Kawai (Kobe University, Kobe, Japan) to determine the relationships among the heterokont classes by generating two large molecular data sets. Currently, 14 taxonomic classes of heterokont algae are recognized, and they include over 100,000 described species (as many as one million total species has been estimated by experts). Common members include brown seaweeds (e.g., kelp) and the diatoms. Remarkably, despite two centuries of light microscopic study, 50 years of electron microscopic study, and 20 years of molecular investigations, the phylogenetic relationships among the 14 classes remains unknown. DNA sequences of seven nuclear, mitochondrial, and chloroplast genes from 270 heterokont algal species and 30 nonalgal relatives will be obtained and, entire chloroplast genomes from 30 species will be sequenced. The genome sequences will provide important new data for understanding chloroplasts and their origin(s), especially since knowledge in this field is greatly biased toward land plants. Algae serve as the base of the food chain for all organisms that dwell in the ocean and account for approximately half of the global photosynthesis, and therefore they provide approximately 50% of the oxygen we breathe. Members of the heterokont algae vary in morphology from simple unicells to highly complex seaweeds. Brown algae are the principal elements of seaweed beds and these macroalgae have high economic values as food and biomass resources. A number of heterokont algae are harmful to marine life. For example, some algae produce toxins that when concentrated in shellfish kill humans, while other species of heterokonts are well-known fish killers. Conversely, other heterokonts serve as a human food source, they are used in industrial processes and they have found new recognition in the nanotechnology industry. The closest relatives to the heterokont algae are the pseudofungi, which include many plant pathogens, such as the fungus that caused the Irish potato famine, and various molds and mildews. Graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows from diverse cultural and ethnic backgrounds will be supported and trained in a wide diversity of fields, including evolution, genomics, molecular biology, computational biology, and plant biology. The research will be integrated with K-12 educators, public museums and parks using already established programs at several of the participating institutions. A Deep Brown web site already has been established, and it will be greatly expanded as part of this project.

ESULTS FROM PRIOR RESEARCH SUPPORT: Collaborative Research: AToL Deep Brown-­?? A phylogenetic and genomic investigation. 09/15/2006-­??08/31/2012. Award# DEB-­??0629521AM03

Stramenopiles are an ancient protist lineage that evolved about 1050 million years ago and represent a major branch in the Tree of Life. The photosynthetic protists (algae) that are in this taxonomic cluster vary in morphology from single, tiny cells to gigantic seaweeds over 200 feet in length that can form dense, underwater forests. These photosynthetic algae impact the Earth’s ecology by serving as the primary food source for organisms that live in oceans and lakes, and by recyclingasignificantportionofthetotalCO2 producedglobally.

The goal of our project was to resolve the phylogenetic relationships within the stramenopile algae by analyzing chloroplast (the site of photosynthesis in a cell) genome sequences. As the program moved forward and technology rapidly advanced, we also analyzed mitochondrial (energy generation site) genome sequences. Complete sequences for ten chloroplast genomes were accomplished. By analyzing 85 chloroplast genes shared by the stramenopiles, and related algae from different branches of the Tree of Life, we discovered that the stramenopile cluster into three major groups or clades and we were able to elucidate the previously unresolved relationships among these groups. Because so many new whole genome sequences were accomplished in this work, we were able to probe how genes are regulated in these algae, and to document how genes from different organisms (such as bacteria) can be acquired and incorporated into the chloroplast genome of a photosynthetic cell . Most exciting was the identification of genes that encode proteins novel to all existing chloroplast databases (e.g., DNA recombinase, viral-­??like replication proteins, modified CO2-­?? fixing enzymes, chlorophyll biosynthesis proteins, and unique proteases). Our whole mitochondrial genome sequencing generated new primary data for many algal taxa that were completely absent in the stramenopile database. Mitochondrial data had a practical application. Information on mitochondrial genes was used to genetically barcode 50 laboratory cultures and field collected samples for an alga (Heterosigma) that forms toxic blooms and is responsible for massive fish kills in marine waters world-­??wide. These studies showed that though this toxic alga is morphologically identical in every biogeographic region in which it occurs, genetically there are many variants of this organism.

In addition to published papers, this project has had significant educational impact. Our publically accessible webpage and database allow extensive analysis of all chloroplast and mitochondrial genomes published to date (http://chloroplast.ocean.washington.edu/home). This research has been presented at regional, national and international meetings. Three post-­??doctoral fellows have participated in this research. Additionally, the study generated thesis topics for two female graduate students, both of whom were awarded NSF Graduate Research Fellowships. Approximately 10 undergraduates/year were mentored thorough this program. Each undergraduate student was engaged in their own project, with a topic chosen to align with their personal interests. Most students presented their studies at the University of Washington Mary Gates Undergraduate Symposium, and at local and national meetings. Application for in-­??house research awards were successful (e.g., the Fry-­??Hotson-­??Rigg and May Garrett awards). Most advance to professional school. Often half of our undergraduates fit into a minority category (including low income students).
